content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy B{B}. Here's why:

The game is repeated 75 times, which gives us an opportunity to exploit our opponent's choices over time. If we both consistently pick R, our opponent will eventually catch on and start choosing B, earning 35$ on each round where I pick R. This strategy would result in me earning 0$ on those rounds. On the other hand, if I choose B while my opponent picks R, they earn 0$, which is a better outcome for me than picking R and earning 0$.

However, if we both pick B consistently, we each earn 40$ per round. Over 75 rounds, this strategy would result in a total earnings of 3000$ (75 * 40$). If my opponent starts to deviate from picking B and chooses R instead, I can switch my strategy to R{R} and earn an additional 225$ (75 * 3) since my opponent will be choosing R when I pick B.

In the end, choosing B{B} gives me a better expected outcome than consistently choosing R{R}. Of course, this reasoning assumes that my opponent is also rational and follows the same line of thinking. But given the number of rounds, it's highly likely that our choices will converge over time.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

Given that both me and my opponent chose B in the previous round, I will continue to choose B{B} for the next round as well. This strategy aligns with my goal of maximizing my earnings over the long term, since we are each earning 40$ per round when we both choose B. If either of us were to switch our choice to R at this point, it would result in a lower payoff for both of us (either 35$ or 0$, depending on the other player's choice).

By consistently choosing B, I can continue to earn 40$ per round while minimizing the risk of earning less if my opponent were to switch their strategy. This strategy also allows me to take advantage of any deviations from my opponent's B{B} strategy in future rounds, as I explained in my previous answer.
